title: How to Clean Sheepskin Boots

steps.headline: Sprinkle cornstarch over the stain.
steps.description: Pour a small amount of cornstarch over the grease or oil stain. Use enough cornstarch to completely cover the stain. Gently pat the cornstarch into the stain. If you don’t have cornstarch, rub the stain with white chalk instead.

steps.headline: Leave the cornstarch on the shoes overnight.
steps.description: Place the shoes upright in a cool area overnight. The cornstarch will help to absorb the oils out of the wool and remove the stain. Avoid leaving the boots near a heater as this sets the grease into the wool.

steps.headline: Dust the cornstarch off with a paintbrush.
steps.description: In the morning, use a clean paintbrush to dust the cornstarch off the shoe. Keep brushing the area until you have removed all the cornstarch. Don’t worry if there is still is a minor color difference between the stained area and the rest of the boot. Washing the boot should even out this difference in color.

methods.name: Washing the Outside of the Boots

steps.headline: Brush the outside of the boots with a suede brush.
steps.description: Brush the boots from the top to the bottom using downward brush strokes. This helps to soften the wool and loosen any dirt that is trapped inside the wool. Suede brushes and products are gentle, making them ideal for sheepskin boots. Purchase a suede brush from a shoe shop.

steps.headline: Dampen the outside of the boots with a wet sponge.
steps.description: Place a soft sponge into clean cold water. Wring out the majority of the water from the sponge. Lightly press the sponge against the exterior of the boots. Move the sponge over the exterior surface of the boots until the entire boot surface is moist. This helps the boots to absorb the cleaning products. Wet the boots enough to dampen them, but avoid soaking the boots entirely.

steps.headline: Squeeze suede cleaner onto the sponge and gently rub the boots.
steps.description: Pour about 1 tablespoon (15 mL) of suede cleaner onto the sponge. Start at the top of the outside of the boot and work your way down to the bottom of the boots. Use a gentle up and down rubbing action to work the cleaner into the shoe. Continue cleaning until you have rubbed down the entire exterior of the shoe. Repeat this process for both shoes. Purchase suede cleaner from a shoe shop. Don’t press too hard when you rub as this can harm the wool. If you find your sponge is getting dirty, rinse your sponge in water, wring it out and reapply the suede cleaner before continuing to clean the boots.

steps.headline: Rinse the boots under a high-pressure tap.
steps.description: Hold the boots upside down and place them under the tap. Turn the tap to the highest water pressure. Rotate the shoe to remove all the suede cleaner suds. Do this as quickly as possible to avoid soaking the boots in too much water.

steps.headline: Stuff the boots with crumpled paper towels.
steps.description: Rip off a paper towel from the roll and crumple it into a ball. Stuff the paper towel into the toe of the boot. Continue to crumple paper towels and stuff them into the boot until you have filled the boot to the top. This stops the boots from shrinking or losing their shape while they dry. Push the paper towels down when you are packing them in. This will create a firmer support for the boots while they dry.

steps.headline: Leave the boots to dry for 48 hours.
steps.description: Place the boots upright in a cool and dry area for 48 hours. Don’t leave the boots in the sun or close to the heater as this can warp the shape of the boots. Once the boots are dry, remove the paper towels from the inside of the boots.

steps.headline: Spray the exterior of the boots with a protective spray.
steps.description: Liberally spray the entire outside of the boots with a protective suede or sheepskin spray. This helps to protect the boots from moisture and staining. Leave the boots to dry for 24 hours before wearing them. Purchase protective spray at a shoe store.

steps.headline: Place baking soda and cornstarch into a bowl.
steps.description: Measure 2 teaspoons (3 grams) of baking soda and 2 teaspoons (3 grams) of cornstarch into a small bowl. These ingredients have natural deodorizing properties. If you are deodorizing 2 pairs of shoes, double the quantities of baking soda and cornstarch.

steps.headline: Mix the cornstarch and baking soda thoroughly.
steps.description: Stir the powder using a teaspoon. Use circular stirring motions to combine the 2 powders. If there are any lumps, use the back of the spoon to flatten them.

steps.headline: Measure half of the mixture into each shoe.
steps.description: Place 2 teaspoons (3 grams) of the powder into the opening of each shoe. Place the mixture onto the foot pads in each boot, rather than on the walls of the boot.

steps.headline: Hold cardboard over the boot hole and shake the boot vigorously.
steps.description: Push the face of a piece of cardboard against the hole of the boot. Shake the boot up and down for 10 seconds. Continue to hold the cardboard firmly against the boot opening as you shake the boot. Repeat this process for both boots. Remove the cardboard and check that the entire insides of the boots are covered with powder. If they aren’t, give them another shake.

steps.headline: Let the boots sit with the powder in them overnight, then shake them out.
steps.description: In the morning, take the boots outside to shake out the powder. Hold the boots upside down and give them a vigorous shake. If there is any residual powder left, hold the boots upside down and bang on the soles of the boots.

tyn: Removing Grease Stains from the Boots
Washing the Outside of the Boots
text: Removing Grease Stains Sprinkle cornstarch over the stain. Pour a small amount of cornstarch over the grease or oil stain. Use enough cornstarch to completely cover the stain. Gently pat the cornstarch into the stain. If you don’t have cornstarch, rub the stain with white chalk instead. Leave the cornstarch on the shoes overnight. Place the shoes upright in a cool area overnight. The cornstarch will help to absorb the oils out of the wool and remove the stain. Avoid leaving the boots near a heater as this sets the grease into the wool. Dust the cornstarch off with a paintbrush. In the morning, use a clean paintbrush to dust the cornstarch off the shoe. Keep brushing the area until you have removed all the cornstarch. Don’t worry if there is still is a minor color difference between the stained area and the rest of the boot. Washing the boot should even out this difference in color. Washing the Outside of the Boots Brush the outside of the boots with a suede brush. Brush the boots from the top to the bottom using downward brush strokes. This helps to soften the wool and loosen any dirt that is trapped inside the wool. Suede brushes and products are gentle, making them ideal for sheepskin boots. Purchase a suede brush from a shoe shop. Dampen the outside of the boots with a wet sponge. Place a soft sponge into clean cold water. Wring out the majority of the water from the sponge. Lightly press the sponge against the exterior of the boots. Move the sponge over the exterior surface of the boots until the entire boot surface is moist. This helps the boots to absorb the cleaning products. Wet the boots enough to dampen them, but avoid soaking the boots entirely. Squeeze suede cleaner onto the sponge and gently rub the boots. Pour about 1 tablespoon (15 mL) of suede cleaner onto the sponge. Start at the top of the outside of the boot and work your way down to the bottom of the boots. Use a gentle up and down rubbing action to work the cleaner into the shoe. Continue cleaning until you have rubbed down the entire exterior of the shoe. Repeat this process for both shoes. Purchase suede cleaner from a shoe shop. Don’t press too hard when you rub as this can harm the wool. If you find your sponge is getting dirty, rinse your sponge in water, wring it out and reapply the suede cleaner before continuing to clean the boots. Rinse the boots under a high-pressure tap. Hold the boots upside down and place them under the tap. Turn the tap to the highest water pressure. Rotate the shoe to remove all the suede cleaner suds. Do this as quickly as possible to avoid soaking the boots in too much water. Stuff the boots with crumpled paper towels. Rip off a paper towel from the roll and crumple it into a ball. Stuff the paper towel into the toe of the boot. Continue to crumple paper towels and stuff them into the boot until you have filled the boot to the top. This stops the boots from shrinking or losing their shape while they dry. Push the paper towels down when you are packing them in. This will create a firmer support for the boots while they dry. Leave the boots to dry for 48 hours. Place the boots upright in a cool and dry area for 48 hours. Don’t leave the boots in the sun or close to the heater as this can warp the shape of the boots. Once the boots are dry, remove the paper towels from the inside of the boots. Spray the exterior of the boots with a protective spray. Liberally spray the entire outside of the boots with a protective suede or sheepskin spray. This helps to protect the boots from moisture and staining. Leave the boots to dry for 24 hours before wearing them. Purchase protective spray at a shoe store. Deodorizing the Boots Place baking soda and cornstarch into a bowl. Measure 2 teaspoons (3 grams) of baking soda and 2 teaspoons (3 grams) of cornstarch into a small bowl. These ingredients have natural deodorizing properties. If you are deodorizing 2 pairs of shoes, double the quantities of baking soda and cornstarch. Mix the cornstarch and baking soda thoroughly. Stir the powder using a teaspoon. Use circular stirring motions to combine the 2 powders. If there are any lumps, use the back of the spoon to flatten them. Measure half of the mixture into each shoe. Place 2 teaspoons (3 grams) of the powder into the opening of each shoe. Place the mixture onto the foot pads in each boot, rather than on the walls of the boot. Hold cardboard over the boot hole and shake the boot vigorously. Push the face of a piece of cardboard against the hole of the boot. Shake the boot up and down for 10 seconds. Continue to hold the cardboard firmly against the boot opening as you shake the boot. Repeat this process for both boots. Remove the cardboard and check that the entire insides of the boots are covered with powder. If they aren’t, give them another shake. Let the boots sit with the powder in them overnight, then shake them out. In the morning, take the boots outside to shake out the powder. Hold the boots upside down and give them a vigorous shake. If there is any residual powder left, hold the boots upside down and bang on the soles of the boots.
sentences: Removing Grease Stains Sprinkle cornstarch over the stain.
Pour a small amount of cornstarch over the grease or oil stain.
Use enough cornstarch to completely cover the stain.
Gently pat the cornstarch into the stain.
If you don’t have cornstarch, rub the stain with white chalk instead.
Leave the cornstarch on the shoes overnight.
Place the shoes upright in a cool area overnight.
The cornstarch will help to absorb the oils out of the wool and remove the stain.
Avoid leaving the boots near a heater as this sets the grease into the wool.
Dust the cornstarch off with a paintbrush.
In the morning, use a clean paintbrush to dust the cornstarch off the shoe.
Keep brushing the area until you have removed all the cornstarch.
Don’t worry if there is still is a minor color difference between the stained area and the rest of the boot.
Washing the boot should even out this difference in color.
Washing the Outside of the Boots Brush the outside of the boots with a suede brush.
Brush the boots from the top to the bottom using downward brush strokes.
This helps to soften the wool and loosen any dirt that is trapped inside the wool.
Suede brushes and products are gentle, making them ideal for sheepskin boots.
Purchase a suede brush from a shoe shop.
Dampen the outside of the boots with a wet sponge.
Place a soft sponge into clean cold water.
Wring out the majority of the water from the sponge.
Lightly press the sponge against the exterior of the boots.
Move the sponge over the exterior surface of the boots until the entire boot surface is moist.
This helps the boots to absorb the cleaning products.
Wet the boots enough to dampen them, but avoid soaking the boots entirely.
Squeeze suede cleaner onto the sponge and gently rub the boots.
Pour about 1 tablespoon (15 mL) of suede cleaner onto the sponge.
Start at the top of the outside of the boot and work your way down to the bottom of the boots.
Use a gentle up and down rubbing action to work the cleaner into the shoe.
Continue cleaning until you have rubbed down the entire exterior of the shoe.
Repeat this process for both shoes.
Purchase suede cleaner from a shoe shop.
Don’t press too hard when you rub as this can harm the wool.
If you find your sponge is getting dirty, rinse your sponge in water, wring it out and reapply the suede cleaner before continuing to clean the boots.
Rinse the boots under a high-pressure tap.
Hold the boots upside down and place them under the tap.
Turn the tap to the highest water pressure.
Rotate the shoe to remove all the suede cleaner suds.
Do this as quickly as possible to avoid soaking the boots in too much water.
Stuff the boots with crumpled paper towels.
Rip off a paper towel from the roll and crumple it into a ball.
Stuff the paper towel into the toe of the boot.
Continue to crumple paper towels and stuff them into the boot until you have filled the boot to the top.
This stops the boots from shrinking or losing their shape while they dry.
Push the paper towels down when you are packing them in.
This will create a firmer support for the boots while they dry.
Leave the boots to dry for 48 hours.
Place the boots upright in a cool and dry area for 48 hours.
Don’t leave the boots in the sun or close to the heater as this can warp the shape of the boots.
Once the boots are dry, remove the paper towels from the inside of the boots.
Spray the exterior of the boots with a protective spray.
Liberally spray the entire outside of the boots with a protective suede or sheepskin spray.
This helps to protect the boots from moisture and staining.
Leave the boots to dry for 24 hours before wearing them.
Purchase protective spray at a shoe store.
Deodorizing the Boots Place baking soda and cornstarch into a bowl.
Measure 2 teaspoons (3 grams) of baking soda and 2 teaspoons (3 grams) of cornstarch into a small bowl.
These ingredients have natural deodorizing properties.
If you are deodorizing 2 pairs of shoes, double the quantities of baking soda and cornstarch.
Mix the cornstarch and baking soda thoroughly.
Stir the powder using a teaspoon.
Use circular stirring motions to combine the 2 powders.
If there are any lumps, use the back of the spoon to flatten them.
Measure half of the mixture into each shoe.
Place 2 teaspoons (3 grams) of the powder into the opening of each shoe.
Place the mixture onto the foot pads in each boot, rather than on the walls of the boot.
Hold cardboard over the boot hole and shake the boot vigorously.
Push the face of a piece of cardboard against the hole of the boot.
Shake the boot up and down for 10 seconds.
Continue to hold the cardboard firmly against the boot opening as you shake the boot.
Repeat this process for both boots.
Remove the cardboard and check that the entire insides of the boots are covered with powder.
If they aren’t, give them another shake.
Let the boots sit with the powder in them overnight, then shake them out.
In the morning, take the boots outside to shake out the powder.
Hold the boots upside down and give them a vigorous shake.
If there is any residual powder left, hold the boots upside down and bang on the soles of the boots.
